fields.headline: Joachim Kühn, Poison
fields.bodyText: German pianist Joachim Kühn has a robust, legit technique that occasionally tempts him in the direction of overbearing bombast, but he usually has enough taste in material (and sidemen) to resist. This high-concept trio album brings together several tunes with druggy associations. Hendrix's Purple Haze is angsty and dynamic, while Gil Scott-Heron's Angel Dust becomes a romantic blues ballad. Chuck Rio's supper-club favourite Tequila prompts Kühn to have fun reharmonising the cheesy tune's chords. Kühn also supplies four originals (including a superb solo piece, Mushrooms) and plays alto sax on a couple of numbers. Poison is the kind of expert, brainy jazz best appreciated while completely straight.
